name: Skye Solomon
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
After reading the reveal and all the information about the condensed timeline, it just seems even more unrealistic. The goal for having a vaccine tested, produced, and ready for distribution by August 2021 doesn’t even take into account any potential setbacks, which would probably be even more likely since scientists aren’t able to spend the proper amount of time researching everything. Even things like building factories to produce a vaccine aren’t as simple as they seem because every factory has to be specialized for that specific type of vaccine, which makes the process take even longer. At every step where the process is shortened, you can see the sacrifices we have to make to get this vaccine. Many phase trials are being conducted at the same time, without even knowing if the vaccine is going to pass the first trial. The vaccine is going to be distributed to some important front-line and essential workers before it even gets approved by the FDA. If we do get a vaccine produced in this time period, there is no way it is as safe and effective as if we had waited 16 years and completed all the steps properly. 

There is no question that we need a vaccine for this virus, and can’t afford to wait 16+ years, but we also can’t speed up the process so much that it potentially does more harm than good.

name: Julia H
comment info: With all this talk of whether a vaccine is possible, I have to wonder, at least in the US, how motivated drug companies will be to expedite the process of getting a vaccine made. Of course, it would be lots of good publicity (and possibly a decent profit) to be the first to make a vaccine, but ultimately, the bottom line is king.Trying to speed up the drug development process could be very expensive and have a lot of associated risks. For example, what if you start clinical trials too early, and your vaccine makes a patient seriously ill. Is the drug company on the hook for that? Are they going to be sued? With drug development being motivated by profit rather than social good, we need to consider whether drug companies will really have the public's interests in mind.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Romina In the first graph, we are kind of looking at "checkpoints".  So 37% failing Phase 1 means that 63% continued.  Of the group that succeeded in Phase 1, 69% of those failed (or 31% succeeded).  If you begin with, say 100 drug trials, 63% of 100 gives us 63 trials that make it to Phase 2.  We can then find 31% of 63 and continue the process to find how many drug trials succeed at all levels.

name: Shivani Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: “A quick fix in a long process”

As I look at the first graph, I think it’s pretty understandable. A drug/vaccine that will be put into so many people should have many phases to ensure it’s safety. It is also understandable that the percentage of failure could be pretty high in some phases. It’s better if it fails during testing rather than during distribution. However, as I look at the second graph, I am concerned. Everybody is looking for a quick cure for the Coronavirus, but the graph makes it very clear that a quick cure is simply a dream. It takes a lot of time to make a vaccine. By the time trials for the vaccine begin, it’ll be sometime between 2024-2026. And, the vaccine always has a chance of failing during trials, especially phase two which has a probability of 69% for failing. The predicted time for a cure is May, 2036. That is a long 16 years which is why scientists are somehow finding a way to make a cure in just 1 year. All I can wonder is, how? The coronavirus could mutate and change, so how can we make a cure so fast? And, will we just have to make a new vaccine as time goes by? Will it even be as effective and safe as a vaccine that took on the process for 16 long years?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Reilly Johnson --

Thank you for your very thoughtful noticings and wonderings.  I think it I should clear up how to read this probability tree graph.  With each phase, the unsuccessful drags are dropped and the remaining ones go unto the even more rigorous next phase.  Here is how you calculate the percentage that get final approval.  

Start with 100 trial drugs  If 37% fail the Phase I trial, how many move onto the Phase II trial?   Then, take this number of drugs that passed the Phase I trial and put them through the Phase II trials.  How many make it through the Phase II trial?   Do the same for Phase III and the Application process.  How many of the original 100 drugs get approved by the FDA?  Now, divide this number by the original 100 drugs and you have the percent that historically get approved.  What’s is this percentage?  

Right now, there are 254 therapies and 95 vaccines being explored.  Given the historical probabilities, how many could be effective and safe?  Is this guaranteed?  What could shorten the time for FDA approvals?  What could lengthen it?

comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

A vaccine is the ultimate weapon to end the spread of Covid-19.  Today’s graphs show what steps are needed to create a vaccine and how could the vaccine timeline could be shortened.

All drugs need to go through a three-phase clinical trial before being manufactured and distributed in the U. S.     There is a graph of the probabilities of successfully completing the clinical trials process. Also, here are graphs of the entire process under two scenarios -- (1) the typical process based on past drug introductions, and (2) a hypothetical process that minimizes all steps while assuming no setbacks and some procedures waived.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Jocelyn --

Thank you for your noticing, wondering, and headline.
  
Let me explain something.  This may make a difference in your thinking.  For the probability tree graph, it’s 37% of the drugs that complete a Phase I trial fail and do not go onto a Phase II trial.  The same is true of the other percentages.  To calculate the percentage of proposed drugs that go through the FDA process, this is what you need to do.

If you start with 100 trial drugs, how many would make it through the Phase I trial if 37% fail?  Then, take this number of drugs that passed the Phase I trial and put them through the Phase II trials.  How many make it through the Phase II trial?   Do the same for Phase III and the Application process.  How many of the original 100 drugs get approved by the FDA?  Now, divide this number by the original 100 drugs and you have the percent that historically get approved.  What’s is this percentage?  

Please return late tomorrow afternoon when we will reveal the article that included these graphs and a very complete explanation of the steps and challenges of getting a vaccine. replies.comment info:
Hi, @Renee A. --

Actually, the 15% is the percentage of drugs that have passed the Phase I, II, and III trials and are now applying.  To calculate the historical percentage of drugs that make it through the entire process, this is what you have to do.  

Start with 100 trial drugs  If 37% fail the Phase I trial, how many move onto the Phase II trail?   Then, take this number of drugs that passed the Phase I trial and put them through the Phase II trials.  How many make it through the Phase II trial?   Do the same for Phase III and the Application process.  How many of the original 100 drugs get approved by the FDA?  Now, divide this number by the original 100 drugs and you have the percent that historically get approved.  What’s is this percentage?  

Right now, there are 254 therapies and 95 vaccines being explored.  Given the historical probabilities, how many could be effective and safe?  Is this guaranteed?  What could shorten the time for FDA approvals?  What could lengthen it?
